headline: Man Utd boss Ruben Amorim explains dropping Joshua Zirkzee after transfer decision made
body: Ruben Amorim claimed he had dropped Joshua Zirkzee for tactical reasons after the striker became the glaring omission for Manchester United's Premier League game against Leeds on Sunday.

Zirkzee started and scored in the 1-1 draw against Wolves, but has been relegated to the substitutes' bench at Elland Road, despite United being short of players. Amorim is without Bruno Fernandes, Mason Mount, Kobbie Mainoo, Harry Maguire and Matthijs de Ligt through injury, while Noussair Mazraoui, Amad and Bryan Mbeumo are away at the Africa Cup of Nations.

Amorim opted to start against Leeds with six defenders and two holding midfielders. Patrick Dorgu has been pushed up the field to play as one of the No.10s in United's 3-4-2-1 formation, with Luke Shaw at left wing-back and Benjamin Sesko leading the line.

Zirkzee's omission is hardly a ringing endorsement of the Dutch forward, who is one of three senior players a heavily depleted bench alongside back-up goalkeeper Altay Bayindir and defender Tyrell Malacia.

Zirkzee scored with a deflected effort against Wolves to net his second goal in 13 appearances across all competitions. He has struggled since joining from Bologna for £36.5million in 2024 and has been heavily linked with a move in the January transfer window.

The 24-year-old has agreed to join Roma, according to reports in Italy. He has reportedly met with Roma's sporting director Ricky Massara and has been assured by manager Gian Piero Gasparini that he will fit into their system.

However, it remains to be seen whether United would sanction the move, given their current injury and AFCON crisis. Amorim has been clear that United will not be busy in January and has vetoed an exit for Mainoo to Napoli.
“The transfer window is not going to change,” Amorim said. “We have no conversation at this moment to have any change in the squad. There’s a process, there’s an idea that is going to continue.”

Asked about his lack of options before the trip to Elland Road, Amorim said: “It was bad luck to lose Amad, Bryan, especially with Bruno. If you lose the three of them at the same time, any team in the world will struggle.

“You have all the data and you can sense that three guys create most of the chances for us. And if you lose not one but all three at the same time, of course we are going to struggle. The important thing is to understand why we struggled in the last three games in creation and quality in the game. I think it’s clear.”

headline: TNT Sports issue statement after major fault during Leeds vs Man Utd
body: The 12.30pm kick-off at Elland Road was shown on the broadcaster, but fans were left annoyed early on in the match. The sound appeared to cut out at the same time as an offensive chant about Jimmy Saville was being sung by the home supporters.

The sound came back after about three minutes, prompting commentator Darren Fletcher to say: "It seems like we're back apologies for that can't wait for the avalanche of positivity on social media. sorry to spoil the day".
Another wrote: "Love watching TNT with no sound, exactly how I wanted to spend my time watching the game."

Social media has been full with viewers frustrated by an apparent delay between the action Down Under and the commentary, with people complaining that big moments like wickets have been ruined by the commentator being ahead of the pictures.
Those complaints were brushed off by the company, which is owned by Warner Bros, who said that no issues with their broadcast had been raised internally.

headline: Sergio Ramos makes final decision on transfer with Man Utd stance made clear
body: Spain and Real Madrid legend Sergio Ramos has turned down a move to Paris FC, it has been claimed. The veteran is a free agent after leaving Monterrey at the end of last year and a return to Europe is thought to be his preference.

Ramos previously spent two years in the French capital with Paris Saint-Germain, winning back-to-back Ligue 1 titles. Noisy neighbours Paris FC have been ambitious since coming up to the top flight, signing players including former PSG keeper Kevin Trapp and France international Jonathan Ikone, but it now looks unlikely Ramos' name will join the list.

According to Foot Mercato (via GFFN), owners the Arnault family are keen on adding experience to the squad, with Ramos' name reportedly considered internally. However, the Spaniard is not believed to have any plans of joining the newly promoted side.

Manchester United had also been linked with the 39-year-old, who was a four-time Champions League winner with Real Madrid. Those links were quickly played down, though, with ESPN reporting in December that he doesn't fit the age profile of the kind of player United want.

There were firmer links between United and Ramos in 2015, and the player addressed those in 2023 after moving from PSG back to boyhood club Sevilla. "I stayed where I should have stayed, Real Madrid, but I was indeed close to playing for United," he said.

"It was not to be, but I do keep that admiration for the club, to the Premier League and the players, because the rhythm of play, the pace is different, and it's a league we can all learn a great deal from, all of us. So that was not meant to be. I was glad to stay in Madrid, and now I'm glad to be in Sevilla."
Another of Sir Jim Ratcliffe's clubs, Nice, have also been linked with a January move for Ramos. However, those rumours were quickly shot down by the club's president Jean-Pierre Rivere.
“Sergio Ramos is not on our radar, that’s not the case," Rivere told reporters. “ I don’t remember if we were in contact at some point or not… maybe. But he’s not on our radar, that’s not the case."

Nice have been active already during the window, with Elye Wahi scoring on his debut after signing on loan from Eintracht Frankrurt, but any further business wouldn't involve Ramos. "We’re working on the transfer window, we don’t have to sign big names. We have to be consistent. Elye Wahi is already a big name," the president added.

headline: Ruben Amorim avoids Man Utd transfer question - 'Don't want to talk about that'
body: Ruben Amorim clammed up when asked about the transfer window and hinted at discontent behind the scenes with Manchester United's hierarchy. The Red Devils are preparing to face Leeds United with the club in sixth position, three points from the top four and three points clear of Fulham in 12th. United have failed to be wholly convincing this term, despite having no European football.
The club were linked with a move for Bournemouth ace Antoine Semenyo, but the winger is set to join Manchester City instead. The prospect of another move in January looks unlikely for now.

Before his team's Sunday fixture against Leeds, Amorim was asked for greater insight into the comments he made ahead of the win over Newcastle. However, the 40-year-old did not appear entirely happy with the situation and gave little away despite repeated questioning.

"I have the feeling if we have to play a perfect 3-4-3, we need to spend a lot of money and we need time," he said. "I'm starting to understand that is not going to happen. So, maybe I have to adapt."
But the Portuguese coach offered little when quizzed on his transfer comments. "I don't want to talk about that," he said. "I just focus on the Leeds game."

Amorim said he did not regret his comments and was then asked if anything had changed regarding the transfer budget he'd expected. "I don't want to talk about that," came the reply. After a short pause, Amorim added: "But you are very smart, so..."

Amorim said in December that he sometimes has 'another idea' than director of football Jason Wilcox when it comes to recruitment. he added that 'common ground' must be found before any incoming arrivals.
But earlier in his press conference before Leeds, the Portuguese conceded it would be a quiet month ahead. "The transfer window is not going to change," said Amorim
"We have no conversations at this moment to have any change in the squad. There's a process, there's an idea that is going to continue."
United spent big in the summer to replenish Amorim's frontline. Bryan Mbeumo, Matheus Cunha, and Benjamin Sesko arrived in deals worth more than £200million.
But the club are now prioritising a central midfielder and could be required to spend heavily again. Targets Carlos Baleba, Adam Wharton and Elliot Anderson will not be cheap.

headline: Man Utd ace considering January switch after biting back at Ruben Amorim dig
body: Manchester United youngster Harry Amass is reportedly contemplating spending the second half of the season with Stoke City. The left-back is currently on loan at Sheffield Wednesday, but could end up trading a relegation battle for a promotion push with the Potters.

Amass, 18, joined United from Watford in 2023 and made his debut under Amorim in March. He made five Premier League appearances last term, also playing twice in the Europa League, but was allowed to move to Hillsborough for a taste of first team football this term.

The young defender hit back at comments from Amorim that he was "struggling", posting a photo of himself with Wednesday's player of the month award. However, he later deleted the comment as it was clarified that the 'struggling' depiction was related to the Owls' lowly league position.

"I think is the feeling of entitlement that we have in our club," Amorim said after Amass and fellow youngster Chido Obi reacted to his comments. "Sometimes strong words is not bad words, sometimes difficult moments is not the bad things for the kids."

He added: "I didn't say anything wrong. I just spoke about how the luck of playing for Manchester United. Sometimes you play for Manchester United and you go see different realities and you understand that football can be so different and that you are really lucky to be in Manchester United."

Wednesday have been hit with two separate points deductions to make relegation to the third tier all but a formality. They still have a negative points tally after seeing 18 points taken off their total after entering administration and then getting a second deduction for breaches under former owner Dejphon Chansiri.
They sit some 32 points from safety ahead of Sunday's trip to QPR, with relegation all but a formality. Amass has impressed in his short time at Hillsborough, though, and has no shortage of suitors.

According to The Sun, Stoke appear to be the most likely winners after a 12-way fight for Amass' signature. They report United won't be recalling the defender, though Wednesday manager Henrik Pedersen remains hopeful of keeping him for the second half of the campaign.
"There is a dialogue between the clubs and the agent, so I really hope that we can finalise something soon," Pedersen told reporters. "Of course, we would love to keep him.

"He has done really, really well. He's 18-years-old, played so many games, which level he has played [at]. Of course the young guy has a lot to learn, but how he has played for us, it has been great."

If Amass does choose Stoke, he would be joining a team with a realistic chance of promotion for the first time since dropping out of the Premier League in 2018. Stoke haven't even finished in the top half of the Championship in any of the last seven seasons.

It's their first full campaign with Mark Robins in the dugout and they have the best defensive record in the league with just 23 goals conceded. They sit ninth in the table ahead of Sunday's meeting with Norwich City but are just three points adrift of the play-off places.

headline: Man Utd's huge January transfer budget and Jim Ratcliffe's net worth as Britain's richest man
body: Manchester United can spend £100million in the January transfer window without getting into financial difficulty, according to a football finance expert. With United pushing for Champions League qualification this season, a lot has been said about their need to bolster their ranks in the transfer market, which remains open until early February.

Head coach Ruben Amorim has already made it clear the club won't bring in players unless there is 'common ground' with director of football Jason Wilcox about which players can improve the squad, admitting that the pair don't always agree when it comes to new signings.

United already appear to have missed out on highly-rated winger Antoine Semenyo, who is set to join rivals Manchester City from Bournemouth. For the most part, the other players linked with the Old Trafford club have been midfielders, including the likes of Carlos Baleba, Elliot Anderson and Conor Gallagher.

Whether United are active in January will also be influenced by their financial situation. There has been plenty of talk about how much they are actually able to spend on new additions, given owner Sir Jim Ratcliffe's status as one of Britain's richest men with an estimated net worth of £12billion.

However, Ratcliffe has painted the picture of a financial crisis at United since acquiring a minority stake in the club in February 2024, worsened by the absence of European football this season. During Ratcliffe's short reign, United have axed hundreds of club employees and increased ticket prices in a bid to maintain the team's competitiveness on the field by bankrolling significant spending on forwards last summer.
But United also recorded the highest EBITDA (earnings before interest, tax, depreciation and amortisation) profit of any Premier League club, along with the second highest revenues, in 2023-24.

Football finance expert Kieran Maguire insists they do not require any January sales to finance further transfers, saying they are “fine as they are” financially. He believes offloading players such as Kobbie Mainoo would only provide additional funds to decrease their overdraft debt, reported to stand at around £748million, while their transfer budget of around £100m this month would remain the same.

Maguire said: “I think the broader issue is they've not got cup money coming this year, they've not got European money. Old Trafford, you're looking to make probably seven or eight million per match, because it's very noticeable that since Ineos took over, the prices have gone up substantially.

“So they're squeezing the fans, and I think that's why the fans are probably a bit more demanding now than they were originally when Ineos came in, because they are being milked in order to provide the budget.
“Again, from an SCR point of view, which is the new rules which are kicking in, they're spending around half their revenue on wages. So they've got huge capacity.

“It's then a case of, can they spend the money? Well, yes, they've got a lot of debt but they're still well within their overdraft limit. What Manchester United tend to do is to buy players on credit. So they owe £466m in outstanding transfer fees for players that they've signed in the past.

“I think that's more of an issue for the summer of 2026 rather than January. If they spend £100m in January, they'll be spreading that over three or four years. So from a cash point of view, it's not really going to make a difference.

“If that's the difference between Champions League and not Champions League, they've got to go for it if it's going to improve the squad. Because a good run in the Champions League, you've got four home matches guaranteed, potentially another three. So you've got seven home matches.
“If you're in the playoffs, that's eight home matches. For Manchester United, you're looking at £60m. That's just from your ticket receipts.

“If you get to the quarters or semi-finals, you'll make another £60m from TV money. And then your sponsors will be paying bonuses on top of that. So there's no reason why Manchester United can't make £150m if they get to the final.

“If they win it, that means they qualify for the Club World Cup in 2029. It's worth £200m. But it's Champions League or nothing. Europa League is okay for a club the size of Manchester United. The conference, certainly for the smaller clubs, they lose money in the conference.”

Based on this information, it would be wise for owners Ineos, the club hierarchy and Amorim to spend well on incoming players this January if it adds quality squad depth and aids their push for Champions League qualification for next season, given the greater financial benefits on offer.

headline: Man Utd news: Kobbie Mainoo receives transfer offer as Joao Gomes update issued
body: Manchester United travel to Elland Road on Sunday as they take on Leeds. Ruben Amorim's side failed to beat bottom-place Wolves last time out.

United began the current season in dire form and despite suggestions that head coach Amorim could be shown the exit door, their form has improved. But within intermittent victories came a lacklustre outing at Old Trafford just before the New Year.

With a trip to Leeds up next, a response is needed from the Portuguese manager's squad, but one member who won't feature is Kobbie Mainoo. The young Englishman is sidelined through injury but has also been linked with a move away from the club.
Mainoo has been linked with a handful of clubs as his situation at United worsens, including Napoli, where players such as Scott McTominay and Rasmus Hojlund have found refuge.
However, new reports suggest that a proposal from Turkey is incoming. Turkish outlet Sabah claims that Besiktas have made contact with Mainoo's club regarding a loan move.

According to the report, this prospective move would be an 18-month proposal and as of now, it remains unclear whether United would entertain it, as well as how Mainoo may react. England star Mainoo currently has just one year left on his deal with United and at just 20 years old, he will presumably be on the hunt to play senior football.

Speaking about the club's January transfer window plans this week, though, Amorim said: "The transfer window is not going to change. We have no conversation to have any change in the squad. There is a process, there is an idea - that is going to continue."
Opening up on who could leave Old Trafford before the window closes, he added: "No, none of them. I don't expect them to come to me to ask [to leave]."
Despite Bruno Fernandes cementing himself within Amorim's midfield, United have been the subject of rumours regarding a new engine-room maestro.
Brighton's Carlos Baleba was reportedly pursued in the summer and new rumours suggest the club are exploring an offer for him in January.
However another name supposedly on the shortlist is Wolves star Joao Gomes. And a new update given by the Mail suggests that there has been a lot of interest in the Brazilian

In a fresh report, the outlet claims that Gomes has suitors in his homeland of Brazil, as well as mainland Europe, meaning that United could face competition if they endeavor to sign the midfielder this month or in the summer.

headline: Brighton chief gives Carlos Baleba transfer update with clear Man Utd message
body: Brighton & Hove Albion CEO Paul Barber has revealed there has been no fresh contact from Manchester United over a deal for Carlos Baleba. The Red Devils have maintained an interest in the 21-year-old since last summer, and it was claimed late on Friday night that they have explored the conditions of signing Baleba this month.

But Barber has now confirmed that not only has there been no contact from anyone connected to United, but his club has no plans or desire to sell Baleba now or in future transfer windows. Speaking to talkSPORT, he said: "No call from Old Trafford. No call from anyone connected to Manchester United.
"We have no plans or desire to sell Carlos in this window, or in any future window, but we know he's a talented player, and he's got a lot of options ahead of him in the future.
"For us right now, he's an important player in the second half of the season, and we're looking forward to getting him back from AFCON."

United spent heavily in the most recent summer transfer window, but it appears that their big spending under Ruben Amorim is not finished quite yet. Amorim wants midfield reinforcements as his No.1 priority to rebuild his squad, and Baleba, Elliot Anderson and Adam Wharton are all targets.

Former United coach Rene Meulensteen recently told his old club to make Crystal Palace star Wharton their top target next summer. He said: "I'm a big fan of Wharton; I think he should be the number one priority for United next summer.
"He would be the perfect player to add to their squad, but I don't think the move will be possible until next summer. He's got great feet, and he is an effective and efficient player.

"He is always looking forward when he has the ball, which is a top-quality trait to have as a midfielder. He's great in small spaces when he is being closed down quickly, and he always breaks the lines to find his unmarked teammates.

"His range of passing is second to none, and he has Premier League experience playing in the same formation that Amorim is playing at Man United. It's an absolute no-brainer for United to sign Wharton next summer."
Asked about his club's plans for the winter window on Friday, United boss Amorim said: "The transfer window is not going to change.
"We have no conversations in this moment to have any change in the squad. There's a process, there's an idea that is going to continue.
"We are near the places of the Champions League, but we are near also for like eight teams behind us so let's focus on the next game. Just that. Our focus is to win the next game."

headline: Man Utd chiefs' messages as Ruben Amorim pressure mounts amid tactical concerns
body: Manchester United and Ruben Amorim's tactics have been under the microscope due to on-pitch performances, but one particular incident this season prompted the club's hierarchy to take action.

Amorim was appointed as Erik ten Hag's successor at Old Trafford in November 2024, but his tenure has been anything but smooth sailing. The Red Devils finished a disappointing 15th in the Premier League in the 2024/25 season and suffered defeat at the hands of Tottenham in the Europa League final.

This season has brought a glimmer of hope, despite an early Carabao Cup exit on penalties to Grimsby Town in August. Currently sitting sixth in the league and just three points shy of the top four, Champions League qualification is a realistic aim for this campaign.

Despite a slight upturn in results, performances continue to be a cause for concern. Amorim has staunchly defended his 3-4-3 system, which he also employed at Sporting CP, but there was a significant tactical shift last month when United hosted Bournemouth at Old Trafford.

However, if reports are accurate, the eventual shift in tactics stemmed from United's top brass believing the team needed to adopt a less predictable approach, triggered by remarks from rival teams. A weekend report from the Daily Mail reveals how a 1-1 stalemate against Fulham in August, where Amorim's side took an early lead only to concede a late leveller, left senior figures feeling frustrated.

Post-match observations from Marco Silva and Fulham's Alex Iwobi proved particularly worrying for United's leadership, including director of recruitment Christopher Vivell, who allegedly circulated the quotes in a WhatsApp group with other staff members.

"We knew how they defend and we know they like to squeeze from the back five," the Fulham manager revealed afterwards. "And if you don't give bodies for them to squeeze from the back five you can create superiority in the middle.
"We know they play with two in the middle, we tried to overload with our three plus Alex [Iwobi]. It was as simple as that."
Iwobi then remarked during a television interview: "We knew that we would be able to get behind their two midfielders and that their centre backs would want to jump – we exploited that today."

United and Amorim maintained a four-at-the-back formation in their narrow 1-0 victory over Newcastle on Boxing Day, but reverted to previous tactics in a disappointing 1-1 draw against bottom-of-the-league Wolves. The Red Devils' next match is on Sunday afternoon when they head off to face rivals Leeds United.
This is followed by an away game against Burnley and a third-round FA Cup tie with Brighton. However, all eyes are on the Manchester derby at Old Trafford on 17 January.

body: Manchester United's priority is to sign up to two 'top' central midfielders in the next 12 months and the club have 'explored' a move for Brighton & Hove Albion midfielder Carlos Baleba for a second time.
The Seagulls plan to keep hold of the midfielder until at least the summer transfer window. Baleba is under contract until 2028, and his deal has the option for a one-year extension.

The report claims that Brighton's star is one of six players currently of interest to United. Nottingham Forest's Elliot Anderson, Crystal Palace's Adam Wharton and Wolves' Joao Gomes are all on the club's shortlist and would command a significant fee.

Ruben Amorim's side also have younger prospects on their agenda in Lille's Ayyoub Bouaddi and Olympiakos' Christos Mouzakitis. The club are expected to make a move this month if a unique market opportunity arises.
United boss Amorim is expecting a quiet January, however. The 40-year-old played down any prospects of deals during his press conference ahead of Leeds.
"The transfer window is not going to change," said Amorim on Friday. "We have no conversations at this moment to have any change in the squad.

"There's a process, there's an idea that is going to continue. We are near the places of the Champions League, but we are also near like eight teams behind us. So let's focus on the next game, just that. Our focus is to win the next game."
"No, none have asked. I don't expect them to come to me and ask anything," Amorim added when questioned about wantaway stars.
United are in transfer talks over the future of Harry Amass, however. The youngster is currently on loan at Sheffield Wednesday but could play his final game for the Championship side this weekend.

The Owls want to extend his move until the end of the season. Stoke and Millwall have been named as two of 12 clubs that have expressed an interest in landing Amass in January as competition heats up.

headline: Man Utd star who won 5 Premier League titles blew entire fortune and was declared bankrupt
body: One would think anyone boasting five Premier League titles and a pair of Champions League winners' medals would be financially secure for life. Yet former Manchester United star Wes Brown discovered just how rapidly fortunes can change.

Football supporters were stunned when the 23-cap former England international declared bankruptcy in 2023. Brown was part of Sir Alex Ferguson's most iconic era and the historic treble-winning side of 1999, even providing an assist to Cristiano Ronaldo during the 2008 Champions League final victory against Chelsea.

Yet a series of poor investments coupled with insufficient guidance on managing his wealth sent Brown spiralling into financial difficulty. Despite pocketing as much as £50,000 per week during his playing days, he found himself desperately trying to raise cash after hanging up his boots.

The 46-year-old is now in a far better position and has navigated through the worst of his money troubles. Brown has been refreshingly honest about his experience and how his broadcasting work alongside various other ventures enabled him to overcome what he called "a tough ride."

"Well luckily I still work, so that's good," he told William Hill in November 2024. "But it's all been sorted now in the sense that I know what I need to do and everybody is happy with everything. So I'm just getting on with it now and carrying on really.

"It was a tough ride, it's something that is hard to deal with on your own at times. But luckily I still do quite a lot of work and I'm able to carry on now moving forward. Today I'm one more day out of it."

Brown kept quiet about his bankruptcy petition from HMRC for 12 months after it became public knowledge. However, he eventually reached a place where he was able to open up about the difficult period.

In total, the retired defender bagged 11 major trophies during his 15-year stint as part of United's first team. Brown first joined the club's academy at age 12 and later became one of only two players to have won the Jimmy Murphy Player of the Year award on two occasions (Ryan Giggs being the other).
Brown has since focused on educating athletes on financial literacy and due diligence, something he has suggested was lacking at the peak of his own football fame.

"For me it was more of a case of not knowing who I could speak to about stuff," he continued. "Sometimes it's just a feeling of, 'I'm not sure that was the right thing to do.' But then you leave it, you sort of forget about yourself, and then something pops up about it.

"But I always feel if I could have the time again I would have more people in the room, and would have taken advice from people. But that wasn't available at the time. If anything, with that you get the pros and cons, and I feel that's much easier doing when you've got people you trust in the room."

Brown is not the only athlete to face financial difficulties post-playing career. Liverpool legend John Barnes has encountered numerous bankruptcy petitions over the years, with the most recent one surfacing last year due to unpaid debts amounting to £1.5million.
Ex-Manchester City star Trevor Sinclair was also declared bankrupt in June 2025 after failing to settle a tax bill exceeding £36,000.

headline: Rory McIlroy delivers brutal Man Utd reality check and admits he gave up watching live games
body: Rory McIlroy says he has not watched Manchester United play live since their Europa League final loss to Tottenham Hotspur in Bilbao. The reigning BBC Sports Personality of the Year paraded the Claret Jug around Old Trafford after winning The Open at Royal Liverpool in 2014.

McIlroy appeared as a guest on episode 109 of Stick to Football, which they recorded during December after United's 4-4 draw with Bournemouth. Gary Neville called the golfer a "big fan" and asked him about his team.

McIlroy said: "The last game I went to watch live was that Europa League final in Bilbao. I was sitting there going: 'What did you expect? It's the 16th and 17th team in the Premier League, of course it was going to be like this.'

"But it's better. They look good going forward, but they're still fragile at the back, conceding four goals at home on Monday. I'm much more optimistic than I would have been 12 months ago, but I still think there's a lot of work to be done."

After finally winning the Masters in April, there was talk of McIlroy taking to the Old Trafford pitch with his Green Jacket. Asked whether he would during his winners' press conference at Augusta, the Northern Irishman said: "If I can inspire some better play, absolutely."
Ruben Amorim also extended McIlroy an open invitation in a video message recorded at Carrington. "Hi Rory," he began.
"Congratulations for The Masters, and I want to invite you to Old Trafford to show your trophy. It is really important to us in this moment.
"You achieved something that a lot of people thought would be impossible, and we want that feeling in our stadium. So, I hope to see you soon at Old Trafford and to meet you."

Amorim is still waiting for that meeting of minds, and Louis van Gaal was in charge when McIlroy last paraded a trophy around at a United match. It was the Dutchman's first match and the opening game of the 2014/15 Premier League season against Swansea City, which the visitors won 2-1.

The Sun asked McIlory about visiting Old Trafford after he won Sports Personality of the Year in Manchester. They dubbed his latest award "another trophy to take to Old Trafford", the golfer replied: "Yeah, maybe, as long as they stop conceding four goals at home."

He told them the last match he attended was the Europa League final and said: "I was like, 'why did I fly all this way to watch this?'" McIlroy then added: "But they're getting better, there are a few encouraging signs, there's a little bit of optimism around."

headline: Every Premier League club's five-year net spend as Man Utd top despite Liverpool splurge
body: Liverpool's £450million transfer outlay last summer has done little to interrupt Manchester United's top position when it comes to net spend for the past five years. Net spend - which is defined as "transfer fees spent on acquiring players minus transfer fees received on moving players out" - is a term that is routinely bandied about in football.

The Red Devils are regular big spenders in the transfer window and routinely rank among the biggest recruiters in world football. However, their sizeable expenditure is rarely matched by profit earned from outgoings - quite the contrast from the current Premier League champions.

It's closing in on 13 years since United last captured the Premier League crown but a five-year span beginning in the summer of 2021 has Ruben Amorim's side as the undisputed leader of the net spend table.

Their total net spend has come to £-684.61million, which is just -£10m less than second-place Arsenal who've accrued a figure of £-675.77m. It's Chelsea up next with the Blues' net spend total coming in at £-662.04m, as despite spending over £1bn since Todd Boehly's arrival, they've earned huge transfer fees from outgoings in recent years

Tottenham Hotspur are the next club up with their net spend total in the last five years totalling £-569.24m despite their last top four finish coming in the 2021/22 season. That was coincidentally their lowest net spend total across the five-year span.

Rounding out the top five is Newcastle United with a total of £-430.61m - a figure that was certainly bolstered last summer by the British record £125m sale of Alexander Isak to Liverpool. The Reds' position of sixth on this list with a £-426.77m net spend certainly calls to their cleverness when it comes to arrivals and outgoings.

In their maiden Premier League title win in the 2019/20 season, Liverpool actually boasted a positive net spend of £29.14m that campaign, given Takumi Minamino's £7.25m signing in January was their biggest across the summer and winter windows.

Their figure of £-228.6m this past summer tells a different story in what was their biggest transfer window ever, and by some distance. The club broke their record transfer twice, first with the £100m acquisition of Florian Wirtz and again a month later by signing Isak.

headline: opinionRuben Amorim about to test Sir Alex Ferguson's theory on Man Utd's rivalry with Leeds
body: Just when Ruben Amorim needed some comfort and solace, the Manchester United manager has been left reaching for his tin hat instead.

Because Amorim won't get a warm welcome at Elland Road on Sunday. The Portuguese will get a red hot one instead, filled with the sort of poison and spite Sir Alex Ferguson could never quite understand.

Unless Amorim has been living under a rock, he should be aware of the genuine hatred that exists between United and Leeds. Both might have 'United' in their names - but nothing could be further from the truth. This will be Amorim's first trip to Elland Road since taking charge of United - and nothing can quite prepare him for what lies in wait.

Not least because he travels to Yorkshire at a time when Leeds are full of confidence as well as adrenaline, following a six game unbeaten run which incudes a home thumping of Chelsea and two draws with Liverpool, including a point from their midweek trip to Anfield.

The game is kicking off at 12.30pm on Sunday for a reason. To limit the amount of time both sets of supporters have to indulge in alcohol. It has become the norm for West Yorkshire Police to cancel all leave and have extra officers patrolling the game. Senior figures from both clubs have been known to meet with police in the past to discuss security measures.

While former United chief executive Ed Woodward once considered not attending a game at Elland Road, because he genuinely feared for his safety. If this isn't enough to leave Amorim bracing himself for a cauldron of hate, he should consider what Fergie once said about the rivalry between United and Leeds.

Back in 2011, ahead of a Carling Cup game at Elland Road, a large group of Leeds fans congregated outside the United team hotel in the city centre. The atmosphere became so toxic, Fergie was scared to leave the building.

And he reckoned the vitriol between both sets of supporters even exceeded the levels which existed between United and Liverpool. Fergie said: "Historically, it has been there for a long time. I have always said Liverpool-Manchester United games are fierce in many aspects.

"Sometimes supporters can play a bad part in that particular game. But it never reaches the levels of Leeds United. Never. It was frightening at our hotel. We had seven police vans round the hotel protecting the team. I don't know why it is like that. I don't understand it. But it is there and it is not nice."

The hatred is historical, due to geography and the envy of supporters of different generations towards the respective clubs' successes. Leeds, who have no such rivalry with another Yorkshire club, dominated the 1970s while United ruled the roost in the 1990s and 2000s.

Leeds supporters have spent decades taunting United about the 1958 Munich air crash, while in more recent times United fans have goaded Leeds about the two fans who got murdered in Istanbul in 2000. Now Leeds are back in the Premier League, football's long-standing 'War of the Roses' will resume once again.
And Amorim will head across the Pennines to find himself on the frontline of the kind of battle he has never come close to experiencing before.

headline: Man Utd news: Ruben Amorim lays out January transfer stance as Kobbie Mainoo U-turn emerges
body: Manchester United will be hoping to get back to winning ways when they face old rivals Leeds United on Sunday. The Red Devils have endured an up-and-down run of form over Christmas, with one win, a draw and a loss in their last three games.

After a tough 2-1 away defeat to Aston Villa in mid-December, Ruben Amorim's side looked to have turned the tide with a Boxing Day victory against Newcastle, which continued their impressive festive record. However, a 1-1 draw with bottom-placed Wolves – who picked up just their third point of the season in the draw at Old Trafford – derailed United's momentum.

It's Leeds up next on Sunday, before a visit to Burnley and an FA Cup third round tie against Brighton. Then it's the small matter of back-to-back games against Manchester City and Arsenal as the Red Devils look to kick on up the table.

Ruben Amorim has confirmed that there aren't any plans for United to make changes in the January transfer window. The Portuguese boss spoke ahead of the Leeds showdown and admits his team are in a good place - but things can change quickly.
Amorim said: "The transfer window is not going to change. We have no conversation to have any change in the squad. There is a process, there is an idea - that is going to continue.
"We are near places of the Champions League but we are also near eight teams behind us."
When asked if any current United player has requested to leave, the 40-year-old shut down the notion of any planned departures.
He added: "No, none of them. I don't expect them to come to me to ask [to leave]."

Kobbie Mainoo is adamant he will be successful at Manchester United despite reports linking him to an Old Trafford exit. The academy star made an incredible start to his career at Old Trafford under Erik ten Hag but his relationship with Amorim has not been the same.

According to The Sun, the working relationship between Mainoo’s camp and Amorim was strained even before the midfielder’s half-brother wore a ‘Free Kobbie Mainoo’ T-shirt at Old Trafford in December 2025.

Despite this - and links to other clubs - Mainoo made something of a U-turn and is determined to revive his United career. Amorim has made it clear the 20-year-old is going nowhere, having blocked the chance of a loan move last summer and now confirmed that he doesn't plan on losing any of his squad in January.

Mainoo will hope to gain important minutes upon his return from injury as England gear up for the World Cup in the summer. The midfielder may see a route to Thomas Tuchel's squad if he can somehow force his way into Amorim's plans during the second half of the season.

headline: Man Utd handed Carlos Baleba transfer timeline after opening January talks for £100m star
body: Manchester United are 'exploring' a move for Brighton & Hove Albion midfielder Carlos Baleba. The Red Devils have maintained an interest in the 21-year-old since last summer.
The £100million-rated Baleba's current Brighton deal runs until 2028 and has the option of a one-year extension. He is currently impressing for Cameroon at the Africa Cup of Nations in Morocco.

United spent heavily in the most recent summer transfer window, but it appears that the Reds' big spending under Ruben Amorim is not finished quite yet. Amorim wants midfield reinforcements as his No.1 priority to rebuild his squad.

Elliot Anderson of Nottingham Forest and Baleba are targets, but former United coach Rene Meulensteen told his old club recently to make Crystal Palace star Adam Wharton their top target next summer. “I’m a big fan of Wharton; I think he should be the number one priority for United next summer," the Dutchman said via BestNewBingoSites.
“He would be the perfect player to add to their squad, but I don’t think the move will be possible until next summer. He’s got great feet, and he is an effective and efficient player.

“He is always looking forward when he has the ball, which is a top-quality trait to have as a midfielder. He’s great in small spaces when he is being closed down quickly, and he always breaks the lines to find his unmarked teammates.

“His range of passing is second to none, and he has Premier League experience playing in the same formation that Amorim is playing at Man United. It’s an absolute no-brainer for United to sign Wharton next summer.”
Meanwhile, Reds boss Amorim suggested on Friday afternoon that there will not be any major reinforcements this month. He said: “The transfer window is not going to change.
“We have no conversations in this moment to have any change in the squad. There’s a process, there’s an idea that is going to continue.
“We are near the places of the Champions League, but we are near also for like eight teams behind us, so let’s focus on the next game. Just that. Our focus is to win the next game.”

headline: Man Utd predicted XI vs Leeds as Ruben Amorim handed major problem
body: Ruben Amorim will have some big decisions to make for his Manchester United starting lineup when they travel to Elland Road on Sunday. The Red Devils will be hoping to bounce back after dropping points against the Premier League's bottom side, Wolves.

Portuguese coach Amorim will have limited options to choose from for the trip to Yorkshire, however. United will take a depleted squad after Bruno Fernandes, Harry Maguire, Matthijs de Ligt and Mason Mount have all picked up injuries for the busiest period of the season.

To compound matters, Amorim can still not choose Bryan Mbeumo, Amad or Noussair Mazraoui after they progressed to the last-16 at AFCON with Cameroon, Morocco and Ivory Coast. United's boss relented in his tactical rigidity to change formation for a 1-0 win over Newcastle on Boxing Day.

A 1-1 draw against Wolves quickly dispelled any hint that Amorim would stick with a back four permanently. The 40-year-old may have it on his mind to swap back to the system when playing old rivals Leeds, however.
United's boss has admitted he is short of options. "You can see the squad, it is impossible and we cannot stretch the players that we don't have at the moment," he said.
"I will try to put together a team that is ready to cope with that. I will try to read the game and try to understand what I should do to help them."
Senne Lammens is an obvious choice in goal after starting 13 games on the bounce since making his debut in October. Those ahead of him are less certain.

But Amorim could be wise to switch to what worked so well against Newcastle and to utilise a back four. That could see Diogo Dalot, the increasingly impressive Ayden Heaven, Lisandro Martinez and Luke Shaw line up.

With more bodies in advanced positions, Casemiro and Manuel Ugarte should form the base of midfield, with few alternative options outside of academy products. Jack Fletcher was chosen from the bench last time out.
Ahead of them, Patrick Dorgu and Matheus Cunha can attack from the flanks. The former has transformed into a goal threat since being moved further up the field.
Joshua Zirkzee, widely linked to a move before January arrived, should offer some support to lead man Benjamin Sesko. The Dutch star will hope to get on the scoresheet once again.

headline: Man Utd set for Scott McTominay boost thanks to smart clause inserted into deal
body: Manchester United could be in for a significant financial boost due to a clever clause included in Scott McTominay's transfer to Napoli. The Scottish midfielder bid farewell to his childhood club in the summer of 2024, joining the Italian heavyweights in a €30.5m (£25.7m) deal that brought his two-decade-long relationship with United to an end.

The decision to sell McTominay raised eyebrows among fans given United's proud tradition of promoting academy graduates – but the move could prove profitable thanks to a sell-on clause included in the agreement.

As part of the terms, 10 per cent of any future sale from Napoli will go directly back to United. This could result in a substantial payout as the 29-year-old continues to carve out a reputation as one of Europe's leading midfielders, showcasing impressive form for both club and country.

Last year, McTominay was crowned player of the season in Italy following a stellar debut campaign where he played a pivotal role in helping Antonio Conte's team secure the Serie A title. In total, Napoli's No.8 netted 13 goals in 36 appearances across all competitions, earning him a nomination for the esteemed Ballon d'Or award won by Ousmane Dembele.

McTominay has also showcased his skills on the international stage with Scotland, a country he qualifies to represent through his father. In November, he scored a sensational overhead kick as Scotland triumphed over Denmark 4-2, securing the Tartan Army's place in the World Cup for the first time since 1998.

Transfermarkt now values McTominay at approximately €45m (£40m), with two-and-a-half years left on his contract with Napoli. The Italian club currently ranks third in Serie A, trailing leaders Inter by just two points.
A sale at that price would earn United an extra £4m due to their sell-on clause. However, this figure could potentially rise even further, with Napoli reportedly open to offers around £60m.

There are even whispers of a shock return to Old Trafford. CaughtOffside reports that United are considering re-signing McTominay as manager Ruben Amorim seeks to strengthen his thin midfield options.
The long-term futures of Kobbie Mainoo, Bruno Fernandes, Casemiro and Manuel Ugarte are uncertain, while injuries to Mainoo and captain Fernandes have left United lacking in midfield.

This shortage has forced Amorim to field 18 year old academy player Jack Fletcher for 45 minutes against Newcastle United on Boxing Day, and even deploy centre-back Lisandro Martinez in midfield during a match against Aston Villa. Other rumoured targets include Crystal Palace's standout player Adam Wharton, Nottingham Forest's Elliot Anderson and former United player James Garner, who is currently with Everton.

A very odd set-up, whichever way you look at it. Never expected him to play Zirkzee in a game as physical as this, he just doesn’t compete in the duels and he would get bullied today. Chido’s promotion to the first-team squad has been brief. Kukonki replaces him on the bench, two centre-backs among the subs as well as four in the starting XI.

It looks like Dorgu will play in the right side No.10 role this afternoon. Yoro has come into the side for Zirkzee, which is the only change from the draw against Wolves before the New Year. Dorgu was everywhere against Newcastle on Boxing Day, but it will be interesting to see if he can back up that performance. It's also an incredibly youthful bench, with six of the nine players coming from the academy.
XI | Lammens, Yoro, Heaven, Martinez (c), Shaw, Dalot, Dorgu, Casemiro, Ugarte, Sesko, Cunha.
Subs | Bayindir, Fredricson, Kukonki, Malacia, Mantato. J. Fletcher. T. Fletcher, Lacey, Zirkzee.
Just a few minutes away from team news.

United are unbeaten in their last 25 games against promoted sides. By Wednesday night, they could stretch that run to 27, but it’s not going to be easy. It’s surprising United haven’t lost to a newly promoted sid,e given everything else that has gone wrong in recent years, but they have also found a way and their name and status still mean something, especially for teams who are only occasional visitors in this league. Leeds away and Burnley away are games against teams sitting 16th and 19th so should be simple enough for United, but then we know that isn’t going to be the case.

headline: MARSHALL: Ruben Amorim names three players Manchester United can't do without
body: Ruben Amorim has blamed Manchester United's lack of creativity over Christmas on the absence of Bruno Fernandes, Amad and Bryan Mbeumo and said "any team in the world" would miss players of that quality. United have been without Amad and Mbeumo for the games against Aston Villa, Newcastle and Wolves after their Africa Cup of Nations call-ups, while Fernandes limped off at half-time at Villa Park and has missed the following two fixtures.

Amorim's side have taken four points from those three games, but had to cling on to the Boxing Day win against Newcastle with a defensive rearguard in the second half. United have managed an expected goals (xG) tally of just 3.6 from those games and only 0.8 of that came against Wolves on Tuesday.

That dire draw against a team yet to win in the Premier League this season could prove costly in the race for Champions League football and Amorim will again be without his star trio at Leeds today as he bemoaned the misfortune of having them all unavailable at the same time.

"I don't like to talk about that, it sounds like an excuse," he said. "It was bad luck to lose Amad, Bryan, especially and Bruno at the same time. They had more creation in the opportunities than the rest of the team. If you lose the three of them at the same time, any team in the world will struggle.

"You have all the data and you can sense that three guys create most of the chances for us. And if you lose not one but all three at the same time, of course we are going to struggle. Then you have to put set pieces in that. Who is kicking the set pieces? Amad, Bryan and Bruno. So everything is combined and we just need to acknowledge that.

"And then it's getting closer to having all these three players. The important thing is to understand why we struggled in the last three games in creation and quality in the game. I think it's clear."

Amorim's in-game changes have again come under the microscope since the draw with Wolves. With the Stretford End calling for United to attack, Amorim replaced Ayden Heaven with Leny Yoro with 15 minutes to go. It was another risk-averse substitution but United do have a good record for scoring late goals this season and only Arsenal and Manchester City have more than their 33 goals in 19 league games.

"The first thing you spoke about is that we are creating and scoring more than most of the teams. That is a point," said Amorim. "Then I understand the team better than anyone. And sometimes you have the supporters on your decisions. Sometimes you have to do what you think. And sometimes it's hard for them to understand.

"But I know when I look at the pitch, I can understand which player is tired, which player is going to be is going to struggle a lot if there is a one against one all the time. And I just try to protect the team and just try to win games. And sometimes it's the best substitution.
"Sometimes it's the wrong substitution. But I just try to do my best. But you said that. I think there is one team that score more goals than us.
"We create a lot. We have more shots than anyone. So if we have something here completely different from last year is the way we attack. I think we need to improve the way we defend."

headline: MARSHALL: Ruben Amorim hints at Manchester United transfer issues with cryptic response
body: Ruben Amorim refused to explain why he had come to the conclusion that he wasn't going to get the money or the time to implement his 3-4-3 system at Manchester United after revealing he didn't expect to add any new players to his squad this month.

Amorim said on Christmas Eve that he was "starting to understand" he wouldn't get the finance needed or the time required to make his system "perfect" at Old Trafford, but when asked about those comments ahead of United's trip to Elland Road to kick off 2026, he declined to answer.

The 40-year-old cut a despondent figure throughout his pre-match press conference ahead of facing Leeds and had earlier said there were "no conversations" about signing players in January, despite saying two weeks ago he was hopeful of doing business this month.

Amorim has since said he would "have to adapt" to be successful at Old Trafford, having realised he wasn't going to get the tools to make the system he has persisted with since getting the job in November 2024 work.
Asked to clarify exactly what he meant by those comments, Amorim said: "I don't want to talk about that. I just focus on the Leeds game."

When it was put to Amorim that he might regret saying it, he said: "No, no, no. But I don’t want to talk about it." Amorim was then asked what had made him say he wouldn't get the money to transform the squad in his image a year into the job and whether he had been told by director of football Jason Wilcox that something had changed.

Again, he said, "I don't want to talk about that", before telling the reporter, "You're very smart", and ending the discussion. The exchange captured Amorim's mood throughout a tetchy press conference.

His comments on the lack of talks about new signings contradicted what he had said last month about focusing on long-term targets and hoping to do some business this month. He also spoke last week about United's joined-up transfer strategy and how he and Wilcox tried to reach decisions together.
"Sometimes I have one idea, Jason and the board has another idea, but every decision we make, we need to reach a common ground," he said.

"That is really important because you don't need to make everything for the manager because the manager can change, and then you need to change everything. But you also need to understand that the manager understands the way of playing. If you don't reach common ground, the player would not come, so we just try to do that."

United had shown an interest in Bournemouth's Antoine Semenyo before the 25-year-old attacker opted to join Manchester City. Kobbie Mainoo and Joshua Zirkzee have since been linked with moves away from Old Trafford this month, but Amorim said his squad wasn't able to cope with departures and told anyone who wanted to leave they had to talk to Wilcox.
"If you look at our squad, I think it's impossible for someone to leave. But that is... They need to talk with Jason," he said.

headline: How Manchester United should line up vs Leeds in Premier League fixture
body: Manchester United are preparing to face Leeds at Elland Road today. While the table looks healthier for United this season compared to last, the jury is still out on just how much progress has been made under Ruben Amorim.

The Reds have struggled for consistency this campaign and the growing list of absentees is not helping matters. In his pre-match press conference, Amorim confirmed he was not expecting any of his injured players to return to the matchday squad today.

That means Bruno Fernandes, Kobbie Mainoo, Mason Mount, Matthijs de Ligt and Harry Maguire will all miss out due to injury. Meanwhile, Noussair Mazraoui, Amad and Bryan Mbeumo are unavailable as they continue to compete at the Africa Cup of Nations (AFCON).
We asked our United writers to pick their team to face Leeds. Here are their line-ups:
Tyrone Marshall

It doesn't sound like Amorim is expecting anyone back for this game so his options are limited but I would certainly be changing the formation back to 4-3-3. That means Diogo Dalot and Luke Shaw as full-backs and Ayden Heaven and Lisandro Martinez in the centre of defence.

Joshua Zirkzee struggled again in the Wolves game and his lack of physicality and competitiveness in the duels is an ongoing issue. So while Manuel Ugarte and Casemiro are locks in midfield, I'd take the risk and throw in Jack Fletcher after two 45-minute substitute appearances. He has the energy to match Leeds.

Patrick Dorgu can go back to the right where he thrived on Boxing Day, while Matheus Cunha can drift in from the left. Benjamin Sesko has had a good couple of games without scoring but a goal here would be massive.
Jack Flintham

The three at the back system does not work so it makes sense, with the players available, to revert to a back four. Dalot benefits from playing as a full-back and the Reds' December player of the month Heaven is more than worthy of keeping his spot.

Dorgu excelled on the right-wing against Newcastle and his short-term future is certainly in the attacking third. While I would not pick Ugarte ordinarily, he is the obvious choice alongside Casemiro due to the absentees.

I would keep faith with Zirkzee and play him in a No.10 role - it is not ideal but the Dutchman looks better there than he does leading the line. This would mean the Reds switch to a 4-2-3-1 which could put Leeds on the back foot.

headline: TNT Sports forced to apologise for on-air mistake during Man United vs Leeds
body: The coverage of the match continued but there was no sound from Elland Road or commentary from the broadcaster. As a result, a banner displaying the error message was shown at the bottom of the screen, obscuring the scoreboard. The error message read: "We apologise for the loss of sound and hope to correct the fault shortly."

The volume was momentarily down but returned within minutes. When the commentary and stadium background noise returned, commentator Darren Fletcher said: "It seems like we're back. Apologies for that.
"Can't wait for the positivity on social media. Sorry to spoil the day."

Viewers at home didn't miss too much of the action as the game remained goalless after a quarter of an hour. Matheus Cunha thought he put Ruben Amorim's side in front in the early exchanges, but the Brazilian was left disappointed after his effort was chalked off for offside.
However, the best chance came 10 minutes before the break when Dominic Calvert-Lewin saw his diving header hit the post.
It was an important match for United at Elland Road as they looked to return to winning ways following their draw with rock-bottom Wolves last time out.
Pressure is building once more on the Portuguese tactician with United squandering multiple opportunities to move into the top four.

As a result, Liverpool and Chelsea moved above them with their North West rivals opening up a three-point lead in the final Champions League place. A point at Elland Road would be enough for United to leapfrog the Londoners on Sunday and into fifth.

It's an important period at Old Trafford with options depleted for the United head coach due to injuries and international duty. Ahead of the trip to Yorkshire, it was suggested that the first signs of friction between Amorim and the club hierarchy emerged after he discussed the club's potential ambitions as they are linked with Carlos Baleba and Nottingham Forest star Elliot Anderson.
Amorim said: "The transfer window is not going to change, we have no conversation to have any change in the squad.

headline: Luke Littler's telling reaction to dig at Man United right after £1million title win
body: Luke Littler refused to discuss Manchester United's title hopes after winning the PDC World Darts Championships on Saturday. The Nuke blitzed past Gian van Veen in a 7-1 triumph to claim back-to-back wins in the competition.

The 18-year-old landed himself the record-breaking £1million prize-money as his astronomic rise to darts stardom continues. Littler, a lifelong United supporter, predicted that Ruben Amorim's side would beat Leeds United on Sunday.

However, he immediately shot down a reporter's quip that if Littler took the Sid Waddell trophy to Old Trafford, after parading it around the Theatre of Dreams last January, it would be the only piece of silverware that they'd see this season.

He said: "If they invite me then I'm sure I can go along again. I wouldn't want to be my friend here tonight, he's going to Leeds tomorrow, six o'clock train, so good luck to him, but we'll win tomorrow."
The reporter at Alexandra Palace couldn't resist a dig at United as he joked that it would be the only trophy fans would see at United this season.
But The Nuke was having none of it and hit back: "Thank you mate, thank you - don't need to hear the rest."

Littler could show off the prestigious darts trophy at one of United's forthcoming home matches but he will have to wait until January 11 for their FA Cup tie against Brighton & Hove Albion or even the Manchester derby on January 17. However, it would be a tight turnaround for the visit of Pep Guardiola's side to Old Trafford with Littler set to participate in the Bahrain Darts Masters.
The 18-year-old paraded the trophy last year after he, then 17, beat Luke Humphries in the final at Alexandra Palace.
He avenged his defeat to the 30-year-old a year earlier after he burst into the spotlight as a 16-year-old sensation.
After the dream moment on the home of United, he said: "It was probably one of the best moments of my life and will live with me forever.
"I was scheduled to parade the trophy before kick-off but Denis Law had passed away. There was an empty seat there where Denis would have sat on matchday.
"I sat behind Sir Alex Ferguson and was chatting to him for a bit, which was good. It's one of the best things I have ever done."
Despite United's recent troubles, Littler's love for United has never waived with the 18-year-old frequently poking fun at rivals on social media.
The 18-year-old takes particular enjoyment in goading Liverpool supporters after the Anfield club have endured a torrid defence of their Premier League title.

Ruben Amorim's side overcame Liverpool during their poor defence with a 2-1 win in October. Taking to social media after the triumph, Littler posted to social media: "Yanited, Yanited, Yanited. Where's the scousers at back under your rock you go.
"Cause we are Man United and we are never going to stop."

headline: Man United rule out one January addition to squad after Ruben Amorim spat
body: Harry Amass is said to be considering a move to Stoke City for the remainder of the season, as it looks unlikely that United will recall him. The left-back is currently on loan at Sheffield Wednesday, but may swap a fight against relegation for a promotion challenge with the Potters.

Amass, 18, arrived at Manchester United from Watford in 2023 and made his first-team bow under Ruben Amorim in March. He featured in five Premier League matches last season, whilst also appearing twice in the Europa League, but was permitted to join Wednesday on loan to gain regular first-team experience this time out.

The teenage defender responded to remarks from Amorim suggesting he was "struggling", sharing an image of himself with Wednesday's player of the month accolade. Nevertheless, he subsequently removed the post after it was explained that the 'struggling' reference pertained to the Owls' poor league standing.

Amorim said after reactions from Amass and fellow youngster, Chido Obi, to his observations: "I think is the feeling of entitlement that we have in our club. Sometimes strong words is not bad words, sometimes difficult moments is not the bad things for the kids."

He added: "I didn't say anything wrong. I just spoke about how the luck of playing for Manchester United. Sometimes you play for Manchester United and you go see different realities and you understand that football can be so different and that you are really lucky to be in Manchester United."

Wednesday have been struck with two separate points deductions, making relegation to League One almost inevitable. They remain on a negative points total after being docked 18 points for entering administration, followed by a further deduction for breaches under former owner Dejphon Chansiri.
They sit 32 points adrift of safety ahead of Sunday's trip to QPR. Despite this, Amass has impressed during his brief spell at Hillsborough and has attracted interest from numerous clubs.
According to The Sun, Stoke appear to be leading the race after a 12-way battle for Amass' signature.
They report United won't be recalling the defender, although Wednesday manager Henrik Pedersen remains optimistic about retaining him for the second half of the season.
He told reporters: "There is a dialogue between the clubs and the agent, so I really hope that we can finalise something soon. Of course, we would love to keep him.

"He has done really, really well. He's 18 years old, played so many games, which level he has played [at]. Of course the young guy has a lot to learn, but how he has played for us, it has been great."
Should Amass opt for Stoke, he would be joining a side with a genuine opportunity for promotion for the first time since dropping out of the Premier League in 2018.

Stoke haven't managed a top-half finish in the Championship in any of the past seven campaigns. This is their first complete season with Mark Robins at the helm, and they boast the league's strongest defence, having only conceded 23 goals.
They currently occupy ninth place in the table ahead of Sunday's clash with Norwich City, but are merely three points behind the play-off positions.

headline: MARSHALL: Ivan Toney, Kobbie Mainoo and January transfers - Man United questions answered
body: Welcome along to our latest Manchester United question and answer session with senior club writer Tyrone Marshall, who covers the daily goings-on at Old Trafford.

The January transfer window is now open and United could be active this month. Joshua Zirkzee is wanted by Roma and Kobbie Mainoo could push for a loan move, which would lead to replacements coming in.
On the pitch, Ruben Amorim is in need of a New Year pick-me-up after ending 2025 with a dismal draw at home to Wolves.

We asked for questions and you delivered. The responses to those submitted are below. We will be running weekly question and answer sessions from now, so keep an eye on our social media feeds and get your questions in as we seek to keep you plugged in to everything going on at Old Trafford.
Will the club make any short-term loans to plug gaps? Like a Conor Gallagher or Ivan Toney?
It's a possibility. United insist the focus is on long-term targets and anything they do will be to bring forward a move they had planned to make further down the line.

I don't think Toney fits that bill, although I do think he would have been a good signing had United made their move when he left Brentford, rather than now. There is faith in Benjamin Sesko at Old Trafford and any attacking signing is likely to replace Zirkzee as more of a back-up, and Toney isn't going to play that role.

Midfield is an area United will monitor this month. They expect to start an overhaul of the midfield in the summer but could bring that forward if possible. It might well depend on whether anyone leaves. Manuel Ugarte's future is uncertain and Mainoo could yet look to push for a loan this month if his situation doesn't improve.
Do they have the PSR room to make a big move for a Adam Wharton or another young CM, maybe from abroad like Sangare from Lens?

United's PSR position has improved, as witnessed by their summer spending and the willingness to be in the running for £65million Antoine Semenyo this month. The PSR rules are also on their way, to be replaced by Squad Cost Ratio (SCR) next season. Those rules should, in theory, better suit United.

I don't think there is any chance Palace let Wharton go this month. Look at the fuss Oliver Glasner kicked up when they almost sold Marc Guehi in the summer, it isn't going to happen, especially when they are in the running for European football again.
Someone like Sangare would probably be more achievable, although there is nothing concrete there at the moment. Again, something like that may depend on the futures of Ugarte and Mainoo this month.

Get Kobbie fit and playing. How come a first-choice England international of last year can't get a place in our current "star-studded" team, who are playing such sensational football and sweeping aside teams week in week out?

It's been a difficult 12 months for Mainoo. It seems pretty clear that Amorim isn't convinced, although he isn't the only one. Mainoo is an exceptional midfielder in possession but his out-of-possession work needs a lot of improvement. That is why there is a reluctance to play him too deep and why Amorim trialled him as a No.10 and even a striker last year.

His quick feet and dribbling make him a real threat in those areas. If he can sharpen up with his positioning in deeper areas he can develop into a quality midfielder, but to do that he needs to play games.

It's a shame he has picked up an injury when he would have had starts and it will be fascinating to see when he is fit again if he can get into the side and if Amorim does give him more game time when he uses a back four and plays three in midfield.
We should definitely give Martinez a good run at No.6 in midfield. He’s a great defender and great at forward passing. He’s a natural for midfield and could save us a lot of money.
Amorim said back in November that he didn't see Martinez as a long-term option in midfield and we've only seen him there for 45 minutes since, when he came on at half-time against Aston Villa.

He has played there for Ajax and has the passing range to do so, but you have to offset that with what you would lose if you took him out of the centre of defence. He can break lines with his passing from deep and is an excellent defender, arguably United's best one-on-one.
I don't see him getting much of a chance in midfield. I think the long-term solution to United's issues at No.6 are going to lie in the transfer market.

headline: Ruben Amorim's January transfer predictions are good and bad news for Manchester United
body: January is arguably one of the toughest months for Premier League managers. Not only have we reached the halfway stage of the season and fixture congestion begins to ramp up with the FA Cup returning for the top flight, teams also have to negotiate a transfer window.

For Manchester United, the January transfer window very rarely offers much optimism for supporters. In their recent history, the Reds have chosen not to make big transfer statements midway through the season, even when new additions were desperately needed.

When everyone knew United needed to add a centre-forward to their attack under Erik ten Hag, the Reds were left to settle with the arrival of Wout Weghorst in the January transfer window. While the Dutchman had performed well for his national team, the Premier League was clearly too big a step for the target man.
Of course, clubs like United have to be wary of overspending in the mid-season window. It appears Ruben Amorim will watch the 2026 window go by without making any alterations to his team.

He explained in his pre-Leeds press conference: "We have no conversations in this moment about having any change in the squad. There is a process, there is an idea that is going to continue." This prediction is bad news for United.
It is clear to United fans that at least one change should be made this month. In terms of outgoings, Joshua Zirkzee is obviously not a player who Amorim has much faith in.

His substitution against Wolves at half time, despite scoring, was a clear sign the forward has no future at the club. Sadly for Zirkzee, he is not good enough to lead the line for United and, playing deeper in the No.10 role, he is not better than Matheus Cunha, Bryan Mbeumo, Amad or Mason Mount.

The right thing to do in the January transfer window is to let Zirkzee leave, especially with Roma keen. If that deal was done, there would have been space available to add a striker to the squad who could compete with Benjamin Sesko.

However, the claim of no changes being made to the squad in the January transfer window suggests this plan is not under consideration. This is a blow for the Reds as they look to gain some consistency while pushing for a place in the top four.

Fortunately for United, there was some positive news to close out the press conference. Amorim was asked whether he expected any of his players to come to him and request their exit from Old Trafford this month. "No," Amorim replied. "I don't expect them to come to me and ask anything."

If this proves to be the case, it would be great news for the Reds. One of the main fears in the January transfer window is that Kobbie Mainoo will push hard for an exit in an attempt to play regularly before the World Cup.

Mainoo leaving in January would be a disaster for the Reds. Not only would United be losing one of their best academy graduates in recent years, they would also be left painfully short in the midfield. Even if Mainoo only left on loan, a temporary exit would still see him take a step closer to a possible permanent exit.

Injuries to Mainoo and Bruno Fernandes have proven the Reds are lacking playmakers in this squad. The Manuel Ugarte and Casemiro combination does not offer much in the way of creativity, that much is clear.
United cannot afford for Mainoo to leave. If he is looking to stay in Manchester and fight for his place, that can only be good news for the club.

headline: Shea Lacey, Chido Obi - Man United's overlooked stars of the future must prove Ruben Amorim wrong
body: Manchester United have a proud history of integrating academy stars into their first-team early, often when rivals would have chosen to be more cautious. The Class of '92 are the poster boys for this movement and have shaped the United philosophy in the years which have followed.

Even as we exit 2025 and enter 2026, United are still seen as a club who give youth a chance. We only have to look back to last January and see how Ayden Heaven chose to leave Arsenal because the opportunities were readily available in the north west, to prove this theory.

However, while it may be inadvertent, Ruben Amorim seems to have forged a war with the academy players which is leading to an awkward succession line. Alejandro Garnacho was a recent academy graduate who failed to see eye-to-eye with the manager and it feels a similar situation is starting to brew with Kobbie Mainoo - albeit it is nowhere near the same level yet.

But even further down the pecking order, there is some worrying signs of a disconnect between the two levels. Earlier this month, Amorim felt the need to call out Harry Amass, currently at Sheffield Wednesday, and Chido Obi for sending subtle messages to him on Instagram.

"Sometimes strong words is not bad words, sometimes difficult moments is not the bad things for the kids," Amorim told a largely stunned press conference. "We don't need to be always with accolades in everything in every situation, we are not helping.

"That's why when you guys talk about a lot of players nowadays that they go against the clubs and everything happened because they feel entitlement. I think it's something in our club, and we talk about the players sometimes forget about what it means to play for Manchester United.

"We as a club sometimes forget who we are and that's that's the feeling that I have. I understand everything is the environment, is the moment of the players, the kids they feel entitled. They feel free to respond to the manager with a picture, my office is open, nobody is coming to talk to me."

Since then, Amorim has needed to rely on the youngsters just to fill his squad. Obi made the bench alongside Shea Lacey, Tyler Fletcher, and his twin Jack, Tyler Fredricson and Bendito Mantato. Only Jack Fletcher and Mantato were brought on to face the Premier League's worst club Wolves.
Fletcher and Fredricson's place as unused substitutes made sense considering they are a midfielder and defender respectively. But the decision to overlook Obi and Lacey was surprising.

It left many wondering why the duo were picked on the bench if they were going to be ignored when the team needs a goal, despite being attackers. Perhaps sensing a backlash, Amorim went on the offensive post-match.

"It's completely different and you know that when there is a lot of new people in different positions and you put one young kid, he will struggle," the United manager said assuredly. "It's completely different when you have a base, everything is working well and you can give minutes to a young kid.

"You look at the game and you understand clearly and you see our team and you know that you are going to struggle in certain aspects and I think that was what happened during the game." The way Amorim suggested things would go from bad to worse if he had thrown in more young players, should grate the academy stars' nerves.

They should be feeling hard done by because, regardless of the lack of options, they were first-team players on Tuesday night and when the game needed attackers, they were overlooked. That should fuel something in them now to prove Amorim wrong.

Like the United boss said in the middle of this month, this does not mean Obi and Lacey should take to Instagram to send subtle but immature messages to the manager. Instead, the objective should be to knuckle down and prove to Amorim he has misjudged their talents and they can actually be brought on to make a difference.

While United have so many players out, Amorim will need to continue using academy players on his bench. Eventually, there will come a time when the Reds' boss bites the bullet and gives them a chance to impress and just like Fletcher has done, they need to take it.
